definition: **noun / hi-fi performance spec.** The **natural resonant frequency created by the mass of the tone-arm and the compliance of the cartridge's cantilever suspension** — ideally falls between 8-12 Hz to avoid rumble or audible bass-boost. This mechanical interaction forms a spring-mass system where the effective mass of the tonearm (typically 5-25 grams) combines with the cartridge's compliance (measured in micrometers per millinewton) to create a resonant peak. If resonance occurs below 8 Hz, the system becomes susceptible to warp-induced mistracking and low-frequency motor rumble; above 12 Hz, it enters the audible bass region, causing muddy low-end response and potential feedback issues. The phenomenon became critical with the shift from ceramic cartridges (low compliance, high mass) to moving-magnet and moving-coil designs in the 1960s-70s, when audiophiles discovered that mismatched arm-cartridge combinations produced wildly uneven frequency response. Modern setup requires calculating resonance using the formula: f = 1000 / (6.28 × √(M × C)), where M is effective mass and C is compliance. High-end manufacturers now publish detailed specifications, and dedicated test records with subsonic tones allow precise measurement. Proper matching remains one of analog playback's most overlooked yet sonically significant variables.
etymology: Term emerged in audio engineering literature during the 1960s as lightweight tonearm designs and high-compliance cartridges created previously unknown matching problems in turntable systems.
